node.title: Error running input file.
node.bodyText:
So I am using the executable to run the input file, you have the exact same one. And I keep getting this functionParser division by zero that I have no clue where it's coming from. Any idea? I am afraid this has to do with the libmesh itself.
./cdd_app-opt -i inputFiles/mechanics_phase_material_interface_random.i

 nlx 18 nly 18 nlz 13
 nsx 234 nsy 234 nsz 324
 xlength 5
XMAX = 5 Y_MAX = 5 Z_MAX =  5.210260493

                             "cauchy_stress_yz" "cauchy_stress_zz" } { "phase_pillar" "phase_substrate"
                             "phase_matrix" "n_pm_x" "n_pm_y" ... "n_ps_y" "n_ps_z" "n_pf_x" "n_pf_y"
                             "n_pf_z" } { "curln_pm_x" "curln_pm_y" "curln_pm_z" "divn" "elastic_strain_energy"
                             ... "interfacial_energy_pm" "interfacial_energy_ps" "interfacial_energy_ms"
                             "interfacial_energy_pf" "interfacial_energy_mf" }
  Finite Element Types:    "MONOMIAL" "LAGRANGE" "MONOMIAL"

  TimeStepper:             ConstantDT

  MOOSE Preconditioner:    SMP

To remove this message, set 'use_legacy_material_output' to false in this application. libMesh terminating:

21: ./cdd_app-opt() [0x40ef30]
[0] /home/ahmad68/projects/moose/scripts/../libmesh/installed/include/libmesh/parsed_function.h, line 719, compiled Feb 22 2023 at 13:12:24

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 0 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.

Here if you are iterested at looking at my inputfile
mechanics_phase_material_interface_random.txt

Hello
I dont see anything shocking
Are you getting any deprecation warnings from this input?
What are these ProductAux for? just for a product / division?
We have a ParsedAux in the kernel that will do the same.
These ProductAux seem to be missing arguments too, I dont see what they are multiplying.
I reckon you should transition the input file to using ParsedAux
Guillaume

which line is doing df/dx?
how is the gradient computed? Is this from a Moose function?

Then you should have a look at the parsed expressions.
Please note that there was a rework of the parsed expression parameters, so if you are getting deprecation messages about this it might be the problem.
We renamed args -> coupled_variables
function -> expression
and a few others

Okay, the problem is very weird now. I do believe now there is nothing wrong with the code ProductAux auxillary kernel. I don't think it is even with the input file. The code works just fine but only with fewer number of elements, before it used to be with as many elements as we wanted.
These are the new dimensions, single pillar in a matrix setting on a substrate
nx = 15
ny = 15
nz = 15
xmin = -20
xmax = 20
ymin = -24.9518
ymax = 24.9518
zmin = -60
zmax = 30
and the pillar is placed at (0,0,0) with radius 4.
It is also nothing wrong with the way the parsed function is defined, I believe. I am interested to hear your thoughts about this:
It working when I use up to 15x15x15 number of elements which is very weird. however, the shape of the pillar is not accurate because we are evaulating the function of pillar using sqrt(x^2+y^2)-radius. But when I increase the # of elements, that is when I start getting errors like
ERROR: FunctionParser is unable to evaluate component 0 for 'df/dx' with arguments:
0
0
-20
0
libMesh terminating:
Reason: Division by zero
[0] /home/ahmad68/projects/moose/scripts/../libmesh/installed/include/libmesh/parsed_function.h, line 719, compiled Feb 22 2023 at 13:12:24
ERROR: FunctionParser is unable to evaluate component 0 for 'df/dx' with arguments:
-20
-24.9518
20
0
libMesh terminating:
Reason: Division by zero
[1] /home/ahmad68/projects/moose/scripts/../libmesh/installed/include/libmesh/parsed_function.h, line 719, compiled Feb 22 2023 at 13:12:24
ERROR: FunctionParser is unable to evaluate component 0 for 'df/dx' with arguments:
4.44444
-24.9518
20
0
libMesh terminating:
Reason: Division by zero
So there seems some problem with evaulating the gradient at (0,0,-20) center of the pillar (-20,-24.9,20) that is interface between pillar and substrate perhaps
and (4.44,-24.9,20) is matrix/pillar/substrate common line.
So let's see what is going on here:
Basically I am trying to do this

And before the stress equilibrium problem was computed just fine with as many elements, so we get uniform pillar and something like this


Now with the new version, the code only works with 15x15x15 maximum number of elements!! so you see the pillar phase is oddly shaped in the xy plane, not along the z-direction though


So what I am concluding is the following: For some reason, some points their gradient is giving undefined answer because of this devivision by zero, why is it being evaluated incorrectly there at those points, that is something that I couldn't really figure out.
But I am happy at least that the code is functioning although with fewer number of elements. basically the larger # of elements I use, the more uniform "circular" the shape of the pillar and therefore the better results. I believe there is something with evaluating sqrt(xx+yy).
Any thoughts on this, Guillaume? thanks for the help by the way

This should be doable to debug.
You need to find the parsed function and see why it s dividing by 0 (the last component)
If you run this in a debugger, you should be able to get a backtrace
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

Final update for the discussion forum,
The code finally works for as many elements as I want.
here is what had to change:
I  passed in to the auxillary kernels parsed functions like that:
vol1_function = vol1_function_parsed
 vol2_function = vol2_function_parsed 

and the parsed functions are defined in Functions block like this
[Functions]
  [vol1_function_parsed] 
    type = ParsedFunction 
    expression = sqrt(((x-0.001)*(x-0.001))+((y-0.001)*(y-0.001)))-5  
  [../]
  [vol2_function_parsed] 
    type = ParsedFunction 
    expression = sqrt((z-20)*(z-20))-20 
  [../]
[]

In addition to that, the gradient of the sqrt(x^2+y^2) at the center of the circle blows up which kind of makes sense because it deviding by zero at the point, So I basically changed this to expression = sqrt(((x-0.001)(x-0.001))+((y-0.001)(y-0.001))) where it basically never passes the center of the pillar.
And the solver runs pretty nicely with the correct physics.  Stresses, elastic energies, interfacial energies, strains, phase functions, etc. Thanks for the help

node.title: IterationAdaptiveDT multiple constraints conflict
node.bodyText: In IterationAdaptiveDT, you can use a postprocessor to constrain the time step, but it also takes time/dt pairs to force the time step at those specified times. It looks like the postprocessor takes precedence over time points, meaning if you're at a time where you specified the time step, but the postprocesser gives a smaller value, the postprocessor will win. Is there a way to force the time/dt pairs to take precedence at the given time points, or ignore the postprocessor at the given time points?

Hello
I dont understand the concern. Could you please paste the TimeStepper block and the time steps it takes?
Right now I feel like it s obeying both constraints naturally ?
Guillaume

Can't get to my input file from here but basically I've got:
  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    ...
    dt = 1.0
    timestep_limiting_postprocessor = time_pps
    time_t = '1.0'
    time_dt = '20.0'
  []

So when I'm at t=1.0, I want to force dt = 20.0, but my time postprocessor is returning a smaller value, say 5.0.
The timestepper prints:
Setting dt to value specified by dt function: 20.0
Limiting dt to postprocessor value. dt = 5.0.

I want the time_dt value(s) to take precedence over the postprocessor. My logic is that I want to force a time step at the given time(s). Currently the time points are being ignored.

Why even specify a timestep limiting pp if you dont want it to matter though?
The time points will be reached, it s just the time_dt that is not met.
If you say you want to hit t = 1, 8, 12 and 20s, it will hit them even with a timestep limited to 5s by the PP.
It would do: 1, 6, 8, 12, 17, 20, taking the max PP step or the step needed to meet the desired time points

My PP is MaterialTimeStepPostprocessor, which lags the solution time. I'm trying to force a big jump in time at t=1, but the values from my material models are based on the previous time increment, which was much smaller.  I know when the big jump times are, so I want to overrule my time PP at the specified points.

I m not sure what the solution is here.
We are not going to change the default behavior of that Timestepper as it makes sense.
We could add a boolean to change the priority of time stepping decisions but it's pretty custom.
You could write a custom PP that has complex enough logic to sometimes give the MatTimeStepPP value, sometimes have a larger value

Seems like most options for that Timestepper are for limiting the timestep, i.e., pick the smallest value of all these constraints, but not enough options to make it grow. Specifying the time points was the solution for this question, but that strategy does work in conjunction with a postprocessor. In the case I mention above my postprocessor is actually trying to increase the timestep, but I'd like to force it to increase more, so I want the largest of the constraints.

You could write a custom PP that has complex enough logic to sometimes give the MatTimeStepPP value, sometimes have a larger value

This is what I'm thinking at this point.
Maybe if timestep_limiting_postprocessor forces a max dt value, there could be an analogous postprocessor that forces a min dt value? Just a thought.
but you want to be limiting the pp with this material change? I dont think the pp you have would fit naturally for a "grower"

I'm using an Abaqus UMAT, which returns a value called PNEWDT. If the value is <1 it is suggesting to cut the time step and if >1 it is suggesting to grow the time step. The AbaqusUMATStress class captures this value multiplied by the current dt in a timestep material, so MaterialTimeStepPostprocessor will reflect the minimum suggested time step from all the qp's. This min value may be greater than the current time step, meaning the timestep can grow.
I would bake all the logic you want in a ParsedPostprocessor and use a PostprocessorDT
I still want to use the iteration adaptive part.

On a related note, why is cutback_factor used on a failed solve instead of cutback_factor_at_failure? I thought cutback_failure was for when solves were difficult but did eventually converge.
Looking closer there's some overlap in the doc strings. Both mention failure, so it's unclear to me what the different situations are.
cutback_factor: "Factor to apply to timestep if difficult convergence (if 'optimal_iterations' is specified) or if solution failed"
cutback_factor_at_failure: "Factor to apply to timestep if a time step fails to converge."

oh they're some sort of overlap here.
Thanks the report I ll get a fix
#23660 has the fix for this.

node.title: Quick custom kernel registration / speeding up makefile compile times
node.bodyText:
Is there a quick way to register a custom kernel?
The only way I know at the moment is to run a complete compile of MOOSE with these commands:
cd ~/projects/YourAppName make clobberall make -j4 ./run_tests -j4
For me this takes about an hour each time.  So as a separate issue, I'm sure this is too slow.  How can I speed up the compile process when running the make file?
I've attached a copy of my makefile (renamed as a .txt file to enable me to attach it).
Makefile.txt

Hello
You should be able to add a file and recompile only the kernels file. Make in the MOOSE ecosystem realizes what objects have already been compiled.
My compiles take under 20s most of the time when I've modified or added only a single file.
Guillaume

Thanks - how do I do this?  Do I need to edit my make file?
My MOOSE ecosystem obviously isn't doing what you describe.

Are you doing make clobberall before making?
You do not need to edit the Makefile.
If you add a space in "Diffusion.C" then make again, does it compile everything?

In my experience it is normally not necessary to do a "make clobberall" before recompiling to add new custom kernels. With this command you basically rebuild everything in your app folder from the ground up instead of simply adding your new kernels.
If you have more CPU kernels available you can substitute the 4 in "make -j4" with as many as you have, which can increase speed but will in the end be a limitation by your hardware.

no you should not have to do a make clobberall.
Make clobberall is only necessary if you straight up update MOOSE or libmesh, and even then it s not always the case that it s needed, you can sometimes "wing it"

I think that's it.  I've always done "clobberall" before "make", as I've only ever previously used "make" after a MOOSE update.
But what seems odd is that when doing a full make for an update, I get lines for kernels in modules which are set to "NO" in my makefile.

So you get other modules by inheritance.
The classic one that s unexpected is getting ray tracing because you included heat conduction and it relies on ray tracing for some radiative problems
Ah that all makes sense now.  Thanks!

node.title: Coupling MOOSE with external programm
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I am a new user of Moose and appreciate its capabilities, and would like to extend its application.
I would like to tightly couple Moose with the PhreeqcRm (an open-source, well-documented, and validated software for extensive geochemical modeling). The PhreeqcRM was developed specifically for coupling it with external transport codes and is supposed to be straightforward to connect.
Whereas I found the "MOOSE-wrapped Apps" page interesting, I struggle with the lack of simple how-to instructions. I see the tight coupling as exchanging selected variables between MOOSE and Phreeqc on every time step for each node while performing necessary syntax transformation and processing via a third-party (MOOSE-based) app.
So, my question is: how to do it? Is there a way to export variables to the external code, or is there another (maybe more elegant) way to couple two different syntax apps? I am apologizing if this is a too simple question, I am very new to the MOOSE and to the software development, but very enthusiastic that this coupling would be beneficial for the community.
Thanks,
Elena

Hello
So if you want to call PhreeqcRM from MOOSE, you found the right resource. There's an example of doing this here:
https://github.com/neams-th-coe/cardinal
To do this, you will need to:

compile both codes together (there'll be some basic Makefile work to do this)
write some code that transfers a field (variable) from an application to another (examples in cardinal)

Note: tight coupling is, in our jargon, exchanging fields and repeating the time step until convergence. Exchanging once per time step is "loose coupling" in our jargon.
There are alternatives to our system that are more or less resilient / long term:

preCICE https://precice.org/, used by the UKAEA with MOOSE (https://github.com/aurora-multiphysics, you ll want to contact them to get the code, I dont see it rn)
file based coupling. Just output the fields to a format the other code can run, and read them from the other code, alternate running each code with a script. This isnt as clean but it s easier to set up especially if you are running this on a regular computer.

Guillaume

Hi!
Thank you very much for your answers, I now take Cardinal as an example and try to learn from it, and will gladly use the chance to continue writing here :)
So essentially what I'd love to have is calling Phreeqc from MOOSE copying the parameter matrix for each node, and updating the field -sending it to MOOSE. At this stage, I assume that Phreeqc inputs at each node converge like a flash and no iterations are needed, which is probably a quite strong assumption. So this would be a "loose" coupling then. At the same time, I do not want to build new input files for Phreeqc on every time step, but just want to update variables values - and somehow I thought this will shorten the computational time and thus will be called "tight" coupling.. Sorry for the misuse of this term.

No worries. That jargon is not universal anyway, just local to the MOOSE ecosystem.
Ok please let us know how this goes!

node.title: Defining a function
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
Is there any way to define a function in MOOSE based on solution values in quadrature points?
In my project, defining the function based on DerivativeParsedMaterial will lead to a high error because the value of function is constant inside each element.
Thanks,
Ali

Hello
Why dont you want to just use a variable to represent that solution at "Qp points"?
I think the SolutionFunction might be the best shot here for that otherwise
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/SolutionFunction.html
Guillaume

node.title: Error No standard variable named
node.bodyText:
I used the following, modules/navier_stokes/test/tests/finite_element/ins/lid_driven/ad_lid_driven_stabilized_with_temp_transient.i, to develop a 3D model. When I run the original model, I get the appropriate solution. When using the same model on a 3D geometry I get the following error:
No standard variable named velocity found. Did you specify a vector variable when you meant to specify a standard variable?
Is there a particular reason this is working for the 2D geometry and not the 3D geometry?
Must use boundary conditions like VectorFunctionDirichletBC, or similar vector valued BCs.

node.title: INS on hold with mesh converted to second order
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have been working on an application to study the viscous deformation of a material with INS. Beforehand, I was working with elastic deformation and only needed a first-order mesh with HEX8 elements.
Now, with velocity and pressure at different orders, I would need the same mesh but converted to second order.  I came across the second_order argument that I can pass into my mesh object (as visible in my input file) which seemed exactly like what I need. Unfortunately, after a few seconds to compute the Jacobian, no computer resources are being used anymore and the run is on hold. I don't get any error message, and eventually stop the run manually.
Running my input file with a simple generated mesh of elements e.g. HEX20 (commented in the input file) works just fine.
Any idea where that can come from? It seems like something is off with the second-order conversion...
I could convert my mesh to second order with some lower-level libmesh code but this is what MOOSE can do, so I would like to stick to it!
Thank you a lot in advance for your help!

LU dies
Time Step 0, time = 0

Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 9.658418e+05

    Computing Jacobian........                                                           [ 49.41 s] [  264 MB]
      0 Linear |R| = 9.658418e+05
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to FACTOR_NUMERIC_ZEROPIVOT 
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN iterations 0
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
  Finished Solving              

I think you should consider SUPG stabilization at this point, depending on the Reynolds number. What Re do you expect?
Guillaume

mumps LU makes some progress but it s not quite working yet
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu        NONZERO mumps'
Thank you so much for your help on this @GiudGiud, once again! My material at the moment is ice, so very low Reynolds number like e.g. 3x10-11!
I'm investigating and find convergence having tighter boundary conditions, investigating more!
@lindsayad @snschune @tanoret do we have experience with extremely low Reynolds? any tips?
Are you certain that the problem is nonsingular?
If you have ~1000 dofs or less, please run with -pc_type svd -pc_svd_monitor and let's see what the condition number is and whether there are singular values.

Oh, why is Newmark-Beta time integration being used? There are no second time derivatives in the equations. I would try the default time integrator, implicit Euler, or BDF2 if second order accuracy is desired

One thing that is very different between the generated mesh and the file mesh is the length scale. You have dimensions of ~1e3-1e4 in your file mesh but your generated mesh is of order 1.
What are you hoping to observe in this simulation? You have Dirichlet 0 values for velocity on the bottom boundary; as far as I can tell there is no driving force for flow anywhere. Are you just hoping to see a quiescent velocity field with a pressure profile balanced by gravity?

node.title: nodal - FV variable coupling
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am a new user.
I am trying to model the diffusion of a specie through a pipe and into the fliud inside the pipe.
The geometry is a 2D rectangle divided into 2 subodmains, representing half axial section of the pipe (wall + fluid domain). The fluid domain is modeled with the NavierStokesFV module. For the solid domain I am using the diffusion, time derivative and some nodal kernels to take into account trapping and releasing of the specie. Inside the NavierStokesFV module the specie is represented by the scalar equation.
I am having difficulties in defining the coupling of the specie concentration at the interface between the fluid and solid domain, because on one side I have a nodal variable while on the other side a FV variable.
Any tip or general direction on how to achieve the coupling?
Thank you

Hello
For now we cant couple in the same mesh finite volume and finite element.
This is on our tasks for this year, getting both FE-FV coupling in the system and the option to have two numerical systems solved together on the same mesh. There's a lot of progress on the second task, you could already attempt to do it that way (and do fixed point iterations between the two systems).
If you're not keen on developing, you should consider using a multiapp approach. You can have two applications, duplicate the mesh, and transfer the fields from one app to the other app in an auxiliary field of the compatible finite element/volume type. There will be some projection error but you can use a renormalization to be globally conservative.
See this tutorial for more on multiapps & transfers
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/presentation/index.html#/
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/MultiApps/index.html
Guillaume

Thank you for the reply. Would it be better to do also the fluid domain with FE and simulate the specie with a time derivative, diffusion and advection kernel? (I am not sure this is possible since there is a FV scalar advection kernel but not a FE one)

You can do that.
We have not added the FE scalar advection kernel but they are very similar to the energy advection kernel if you want to try

thank you, the implementation of an advection kernel is straight forward indeed. I am using the INSADEnergyAdvection as a reference. It works fine if I input manually a velocity vector in the input (like in the tutorial Example2), however I am having difficulties in retrieving the fluid velocity vector inside the Kernel. What is the method to get the INS fluid velocity vector?
INSAD is using material properties for residuals. You ll want to have a look at adding a residual that way too, in order to be able to do the SUPG stabilization

Thanks, seems to work great, however I am now struggling in obtaining a conservation balance for the scalar in the fluid field. I am sorry if the question is obvious, but how would you verify the conservation of a scalar at the boundary of a 2D rectangular domain?
Right now, I am using a simplified case where the fluid is still (u = 0, v = 0) and there is a DirichletBC on the left, right and top boundaries equal to 10, 1 and 1 respectively (for the scalar). On the bottom boundary there is a NeumannBC for the scalar (i.e. a wall). I can't manage to obtain a net scalar flux across the boudaries equal to zero (the volume reached saturation since the overall concentration in the domain is constant).
For computing the diffusive fluxes at the interface I am usign the SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral. It is not clear to me what is the best option to get the advective flux (possibly the "VolumetricFlowRate" postprocessor, specifying as advected variable my scalar).
Thank you for the help!

You can use the VolumetricFlowRate postprocessors on boundaries around the domain to evaluation the conservation. It will let you specify which quantity is being advected and what the advecting velocity is.
However, this is looking at surface balance and the FE method is conservative over volumes.
To check that, we implemented volumetric conservation postprocessors, such as this one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/INSElementIntegralEnergyAdvection.html
You should be able to adapt it for scalar quantities.
The SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral is not going to be valid for all types of diffusive fluxes. You ll need to double check the definition of the diffusive flux in your kernel and in the postprocessor.

Thank you. I adapted the linked postprocessor. So it is normal that the outlet VolumetricFlowRate is off by a bit (e.g. 0.5 - 1%) compared to the inlet VolumetricFlowRate, even though the volumetric conservation postprocessor returns a basically zero (1e-17) value.
To my understanding the SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral should be valid for the "ADHeatConduction" kernel (correct me if wrong please), but I am not sure about the "CoefDiffusion" one
Yes it s normal. Does it get better with refinement?

I verified that the quantity of scalar entering the domain due to the DirichletBC heavily depends on the resolution of the mesh (it has a variation of about 20%).
Using adaptive mesh doesn't change this, but causes the outlet VolumetricFlowRate to be very similar to the inlet one (given the indicator I used shown below, this is less true for longer simulations, as the mesh tends to be coarser due to the system being stationary).

To have a proper indication of the quantities entering/leaving my domain I need to develop a volumetric conservation postprocessor only for the volumes at the boundaries I guess (I didn't find a similar postprocessor in the documentation).
For verifying the diffusion term, is it ok to used the SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral if my diffusion kernel is a modified version of "ADHeatConduction" containing only the quantity being diffused and the diffusivity?

Thank you
[Adaptivity]
   max_h_level = 3
   marker = marker
   [Indicators]
     [indicator]
       type = GradientJumpIndicator
       variable = myscalar
     []
   []
   [Markers]
     [marker]
       type = ErrorFractionMarker
       indicator = indicator
       refine = 0.2
       coarsen = 0.2
     []
   []
 []

You may want to make the refinement permanent instead of using adaptivity. To do that you can use a RefineBlockGenerator in targetted blocks.
If you care about conserving an inlet flux, you should consider a Neumann boundary condition.


A volumetric conservation postprocessor will not show you the quantities entering or leaving a block. It will just compute the advection term contribution (with or without diffusion, depending on how you write it) to the balance, which can tell you about the importance of other terms (if you have a reaction term for example)


What kind of boundary are you using the SideDiffusiveFlux on ? Dirichlet ? No BC?

node.title: indentation test
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am modelling a dynamic test where an indentor hits a multilayered sold.
The indenter is linear elastic and the composite is modelled with phase field fracture approach.
I have everytime put block = indentor or composite to distinguish between them.
I the phase field  module action; in the material; in the kernels ....
I still have this error message when running the code.
Surface100_QUAD4 is my indentor. As if somewhere the indentor is said to be like the composite and
needs all the material properties.
saber
regards,
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".

Material property 'L', requested by 'c_ACInterface' is not defined on block Surface100_QUAD4
Material property 'kappa_op', requested by 'c_ACInterface' is not defined on block Surface100_QUAD4
Material property 'L', requested by 'c_AllenCahn' is not defined on block Surface100_QUAD4
Material property 'dF/dc', requested by 'c_AllenCahn' is not defined on block Surface100_QUAD4
Material property 'd^2F/dc^2', requested by 'c_AllenCahn' is not defined on block Surface100_QUAD4

Hello
So Surface100_QUAD4 is a 2D block in a 3D domain?
Is the whole system 2D or 3D?
All these material properties are missing on that block. This physics is defined on that block and needs those properties. If you don't want to extend the material properties to the block, then you ll need to block restrict the physics away from it.
Guillaume

everything is in 2D. The 2D mesh is composed of two surfaces, and I have considered two different physics and do not know why it is asking for  L, kappa_op, ... while the Surface100_QUAD4 is defined as linear elastic homogenous material.

The physics must not be block restricted
can you please share your input?

[Mesh]
  # Mesh block.  Meshes can be read in or automatically generated

type = FileMeshGenerator
file =TotalMesh.inp
construct_side_list_from_node_list=true
  []
[]

  [../]

[Modules]

        mobility = L
        kappa = kappa_op
        block = 'plate'
      [../]
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Contact]
    primary = ContactImpact 
    secondary = impact
    model = frictionless
    formulation =mortar # penalty
    #penalty = 1e9
    c_normal = 1e+2
    #normalize_penalty = true
[]

[AuxVariables]
[./bounds_dummy]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]

[./resid_x]
  [../]
  [./resid_y]
  [../]
   [./vel_x]
  [../]
  [./accel_x]
  [../]

  [../]
  [./accel_y]
   [../]

    order = CONSTANT

  [./total_strain_xx]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[./total_strain_xy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]



[Kernels]
  [./gravity]
    type = Gravity
    variable = disp_y

  [../]

[]

  [../]
 petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type  -snes_type'

  dtmin = 1.0e-12
   dtmax=3.0e-7

[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./resid_x]

    boundary = top 
  [../]
  [./resid_y]
    type = NodalSum
    variable = resid_y
    boundary = top
  [../]
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
 csv = true
  interval =10 
[]

This looks right. I ll need to run this to find out what's happening.
If anyone can help here, otherwise there'll be a delay

ok the Nonconserved action is not well block restricted imo
I ll try to patch this. i ll let you know

I tentatively put this PR up to fix this
#23633
It's still unreviewed so use at your own risk but feel free to give me feedback!

I have considered using the three kernels  separately instead of the PhaseField Action, with this it is possible to specify the blocks.
thanks
That works as well!

for the bounds:
[Bounds]

    type = ConstantBoundsAux
    variable = bounds_dummy
    block = 'plate'
    bounded_variable = c
    bound_type = upper
    bound_value = 1.0
  [../]
  [./c_lower_bound]
    type = VariableOldValueBoundsAux
    variable = bounds_dummy
    block = 'plate'
    bounded_variable = c
    bound_type = lower
  [../]
[]

node.title: Numerical simulations don't show anisotropic features.
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I was trying to solve a phase field problem. After running, the numerical simulations don't show anisotropic features, but the file has the block about anisotropy. I don't know if it's the reason for the parameter, or do you have any suggestions for this?
The complete code is attached as follows:

[Mesh]
    type = GeneratedMesh
    dim = 2               
    nx = 300               # Number of elements in the X direction.
    ny = 300               # Number of elements in the Y direction.
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 5              # Upper X Coordinate of the generated mesh.
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 5
    uniform_refine = 2
[]

[Variables]
    [./w]       # concentration
    [../]
    [./phi]   # phase field
    [../]
    [./T]   # temperature
    [../]
[]

[ICs]
    [./w]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = w
      value = 0.3
    [../]
    [./T]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = T
      value = 2.1
    [../]
    [./phi]
      type = SmoothCircleIC
      profile = TANH
      variable = phi
      x1 = 2.5
      y1 = 2.5
      invalue = -1
      outvalue = 1
      radius = 1
      int_width = 0.405578
    [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  # phase field
    [./phi_dot]
      type = SusceptibilityTimeDerivative
      variable = phi
      f_name = tau
    [../]
    [./AllenCahn]
      type = AllenCahn
      variable = phi
      f_name = Fr
    [../]  
    [./anisoACinterface1]
      type = ACInterfaceKobayashi1
      variable = phi
    [../]
    [./anisoACinterface2]
      type = ACInterfaceKobayashi2
      variable = phi
    [../]
  # Chemical potential.
    [./w_dot]
      type = SusceptibilityTimeDerivative   
      variable = w
      f_name = chi                          # Susceptibility function F defined in a FunctionMaterial.
      coupled_variables = 'phi'
    [../]
    [./Diffusion]
      type = MatDiffusion                   # Diffusion equation Kernel that takes an isotropic Diffusivity from a material property
      variable = w
      diffusivity = Dchi                    # D*chi defined in [material] > [mobility]
    [../]
    [./coupled_etaa0dot]
      type = CoupledSusceptibilityTimeDerivative
      variable = w
      v = phi
      f_name = ft
      coupled_variables = 'phi'
    [../]
    [./coupled_antitrapping]
      type = AntitrappingCurrent
      variable = w
      v = phi
      f_name = rhodiff
    [../]
    # temperature.
    [./T_dot]
      type = TimeDerivative
      variable = T
    [../]
    [./coupled_CoefDiffusion]
      type = CoefDiffusion
      variable = T
      coef = 1e8
    [../]
    [./phi_dot_T]
      type = CoefCoupledTimeDerivative
      variable = T
      v = phi
      coef = 2
    [../]    
[]
  
[Materials]
    [./material]
      type = InterfaceOrientationMaterial
      op = phi
      anisotropy_strength = 0.05
      mode_number = 4
      eps_bar = 0.01
    [../]
    [./speexpress]
      type = ParsedMaterial           
      coupled_variables = 'phi w T'
      f_name = Fr
      material_property_names = 'lambda MCi'
      function = 'phi^3-phi+lambda*(1-phi^2)^2*(MCi*w+T)'
    [../]
    [./mobility]
      type = ParsedMaterial
      coupled_variables = 'w'  
      f_name = tau
      material_property_names = 'tau0 Le MCi k eps'
      expression = 'tau0*eps^2*(1/Le+MCi*(1+(1-k)*w))' 
    [../]
    [./chemp]
      type = ParsedMaterial
      coupled_variables = 'phi'
      f_name = chi
      material_property_names = 'k'
      function = '1+k-(1-k)*phi' 
    [../]
    [./matdiff]
      type = ParsedMaterial
      coupled_variables = 'phi'
      f_name = Dchi
      material_property_names = 'D'
      function = 'D*(1-phi)' 
    [../]
    [./antitrap]
      type = ParsedMaterial
      coupled_variables = 'w'
      f_name = rhodiff
      material_property_names = 'k wid'
      function = 'wid/sqrt(2)*(1+(1-k)*w)' 
    [../]
    [./int]
      type = ParsedMaterial
      coupled_variables = 'w'
      f_name = ft
      material_property_names = 'k'
      function = '1+(1-k)*w' 
    [../]
    [./const]
      type = GenericConstantMaterial
      prop_names =  'tau0   Le  MCi   k  lambda   D  wid L'
      prop_values = '1e-5  1.0  0.15  0.15  3.1913  2.0  0.1 1'
    [../]
[]

  
[Preconditioning]
    [./SMP]
      type = SMP        
      full = true       
    [../]
[]
  
[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    scheme = bdf2           # second-order backward differentiation formula
    solve_type = PJFNK      # NEWTON JFNK PJFNK
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
    petsc_options_value = 'hypre    boomeramg      31'
    l_tol = 1.0e-2          # linear tolerance
    l_max_its = 30          # max linear iterations
    nl_max_its = 100         # max non-linear iterations
    nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-4     # non-linear relative tolerance
    nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-4       # non-linear absolute tolerance
    end_time = 0.1          # The end time of the simulation. Default:1e+30
    line_search = none
    [./TimeStepper]
      type = IterationAdaptiveDT  # Adjust the timestep based on the number of iterations
      optimal_iterations = 6
      iteration_window = 2
      dt = 0.0005                 # The timestep size between solves
      cutback_factor = 0.75        # Factor to apply to timestep if difficult convergence
      growth_factor = 1.1         # Factor to apply to timestep if easy convergence
    [../]
[]

[Adaptivity]
  initial_steps = 3                   # The number of adaptive steps to do based on the initial condition.
  max_h_level = 3                     # Maximum number of times a single element can be refined. If 0 then infinite.
[]
  

  
[Outputs]
    exodus = true
    interval = 50     # only output every 10 timesteps.
[]

[Debug]
  show_material_props = true
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

Thanks!

Hello,
To help us understand what you are seeing, what is the physical system that you are trying to simulate? (i.e. pure material, alloy, isothermal or varying temperature, etc.) Are you trying to implement a model that is already published? If yes, can you tell us what paper it is based on? If no, can you write up a description of the governing equations that you are trying to implement?
You may already be aware of this, but there is an input file that is one of the examples in the MOOSE repository that you can look at. This is for growth of a dendritic structure that has a snowflake-like morphology. It is for solidification of a pure material. This is a useful reference for you to start from: moose/modules/phase_field/examples/anisotropic_interfaces/snow.i

Hello @laagesen ,
Thank you for your reply.
The physical system is about alloy (link: https://journals.aps.org/pre/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevE.69.051607). In this model (eqs. 45, 46, 47), in addition to the anisotropy of the interface energy, the mobility is also anisotropic. I looked carefully at the reference (snow.i) you mentioned. I guess because I put the mobility on the left side of the equal sign, numerical simulations don't show anisotropic features. Do you have any suggestions for this?

I would try to do some more basic troubleshooting of your model first before worrying about the anisotropy. If you have the sign of the mobility incorrect it will cause more problems than just not having anisotropy appear. If the mobility has the wrong sign, you may see a nucleus shrink rather than grow. I would first start with a 1D test of a supersaturated liquid with a solid region in one side of the domain, in conditions where you expect the solid to grow, in that case the size of the solid region should grow. Then do a 2D problem without anisotropy, with a circular solid seed in the center of the simulation domain. In that case you should see the circular seed grow while maintaining the circular shape, at least until it gets to be comparable in size to the simulation domain volume. Once you make sure the model is working for those simpler cases, then try turning on the anisotropy.

Thank you very much.
I will refer to your valuable suggestions. I would like to ask you one more question, how to choose the value of the radius in the initial condition (SmoothCircleIC)?
The value is not critical, I would just make sure to use something significantly larger than your interface width but significantly smaller than your simulation domain.
Thank you very much for your response, which has been very helpful to me. I also appreciate @GiudGiud for organizing the code. Thank you both for your assistance.

Hello @laagesen ,
I'm sorry to bother you again.
How should we determine the value of the free energy barrier height?
Thank you very much.

From Eq. (49) in the Phys Rev E paper, you should use the interfacial energy gamma for the physical system you are working with, then for your chosen interfacial width W, you can solve for the free energy barrier height H.
Thank you very much for your reply.
